channel.title: The COVID Tracking Project - RSS Feed
channel.description: The COVID Tracking Project collects and publishes the most complete testing data available for US states and territories.

item.title: 20,000 Hours of Data Entry: Why We Didn’t Automate Our Data Collection
item.description: Looking back on a year of collecting COVID-19 data, here’s a summary of the tools we automated to make our data entry smoother and why we ultimately relied on manual data collection.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilmour

item.title: A Wrap-Up: The Five Major Metrics of COVID-19 Data
item.description: As The COVID Tracking Project comes to a close, here’s a summary of how states reported data on the five major COVID-19 metrics we tracked—tests, cases, deaths, hospitalizations, and recoveries—and how reporting complexities shaped the data.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman & Sara Simon

item.title: How Probable Cases Changed Through the COVID-19 Pandemic
item.description: When analyzing COVID-19 data, confirmed case counts are obvious to study. But don’t overlook probable cases—and the varying, evolving ways that states have defined them.
item.dc:creator: Madhavi Bharadwaj, Lauran Hazan, Kara W. Schechtman, & Sara Simon

item.title: How Lagging Death Counts Muddled Our View of the COVID-19 Pandemic
item.description: During the worst parts of the COVID-19 pandemic, the United States struggled to keep up with COVID-19 death counts.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Dating Data: How We Used Multiple Dating Schemes to Provide the Most Complete Picture of the Pandemic
item.description: Throughout our year of tracking COVID-19 tests, cases, and outcomes, we were confronted with data organized by numerous dating schemes. Here’s how we came to understand those dating schemes, and the solution we developed for making the best of them.
item.dc:creator: Theo Michel & Rebma

item.title: How and Why The COVID Tracking Project Built a Screenshot System
item.description: A system for regularly capturing static images of state COVID-19 websites helped us produce an archive and verify our published data.
item.dc:creator: Julia Kodysh & Jonathan Gilmour

item.title: Behind The COVID Tracking Project’s Public Help Desk
item.description: Volunteers and staffers at The COVID Tracking Project replied to thousands of messages from the public last year. Here’s why we took the trouble, and here’s what people wanted to know.
item.dc:creator: Amanda French & Brian S.-K. Li

item.title: Releasing Our State COVID-19 Data Log
item.description: From July 2020 to March 2021, The COVID Tracking Project compiled a detailed set of structured COVID-19 data notes, both on changes states made to the data and changes we made to the data we captured from states. Today, we’re releasing those notes.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: How We Entered COVID-19 Testing and Outcomes Data Every Day for a Year
item.description: We set up a set of roles and a shift system to carefully gather and inspect the data we published.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Hoffman

item.title: (The Perils of) Automatically Collecting COVID Data
item.description: Automating data collection published by the states was an adventure full of trickery and misfortune.
item.dc:creator: Theo Michel & Rebma

item.title: Inside The COVID Tracking Project's Volunteer Organization
item.description: More than 800 volunteers performed thousands of hours of work to make our regular data operation possible during the COVID-19 pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Amanda French & Nicki Camberg

item.title: Federal COVID-19 Testing Data Is Getting Better
item.description: The federal government improved its state and county-level COVID-19 PCR testing data since we analyzed it in February. Here’s an update on those changes and what we hope to see next for the data.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Measuring Our Impact at The COVID Tracking Project
item.description: Our largely volunteer-operated effort became a critical data source for journalists, scientists, academics and government officials.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Glickhouse

item.title: Inconsistent Reporting Practices Hampered Our Ability to Analyze COVID-19 Data. Here Are Three Common Problems We Identified.
item.description: With little consistency in how states defined, published, and presented COVID-19 data, it is difficult to compare situations across states.
item.dc:creator: Sara Simon

item.title: Releasing Our Annotations on State COVID-19 Current Hospitalizations Data
item.description: As part of our wind-down process, we are releasing a one-time snapshot of our research into states’ current hospitalization definitions.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Glassman

item.title: How Not to Interpret COVID-19 Data
item.description: Beware of dating schemes, data dumps, weather events and other issues that can lead to mistakes that confuse the public.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: The Decisions We Made
item.description: Looking back at what made The COVID Tracking Project work.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane

item.title: What We Know—and What We Don’t Know—About the Impact of the Pandemic on Our Most Vulnerable Community
item.description: Residents of nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities suffered an outsized impact from COVID-19. And yet we still don’t know how big of an impact, because so much data is missing or incomplete. What we do know makes plain that we failed to protect this community—and at great cost.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Conor Kelly, Erin Kissane, & Kara Oehler

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: What We Know About Race and Ethnicity Data
item.description: Publicly available federal race and ethnicity COVID-19 data is currently usable and improving, although it shares many of the problems we’ve found in state-reported data.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb

item.title: A New Surge Has Arrived in Michigan, but We Don’t Know What It Will Look Like
item.description: According to federal data, COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations have reversed their decline in Michigan, marking a new surge concentrated in and around Detroit, but affecting regions statewide.
item.dc:creator: Conor Kelly, Erin Kissane, Dave Luo, Alexis Madrigal, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: Federal COVID Data in a Single Stream
item.description: We’ve created a bit of code that helps combine federal testing, case, deaths, and hospitalization data into a single spreadsheet.
item.dc:creator: Zach Lipton, Dave Luo, & Peter Walker

item.title: Giving Thanks and Looking Ahead: Our Data Collection Work Is Done
item.description: While our work to compile COVID-19 data has concluded, we will continue to share research, analysis, and documentation in the months ahead. We are enormously grateful to the hundreds of volunteers who made this work possible.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Alexis Madrigal

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: How to Find Data
item.description: Here’s where and how you can find COVID-19 data now that The COVID Tracking Project has ended.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Releasing our Annotations on COVID-19 State Data Definitions
item.description: As part of our wind-down process, we’re publicly sharing our structured metadata on state COVID-19 data definitions.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Testing Data
item.description: At least three different federal agencies share testing data for SARS-CoV-2 in at least four different places. Here’s a little about where that data comes from, what each dataset has to offer, and how you can use the datasets best in light of their large differences from state-provided data.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Our Final Week: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Mar 4
item.description: Tests are up, while cases, hospitalizations, and deaths continue their declines. We are at a crucial moment in the pandemic, with vaccinations ramping up but multiple variants of SARS-CoV-2 gaining footholds across the US. In our final weekly report, we urge continued vigilance in reducing the spread of the virus, and direct readers on how to follow the course of the pandemic without us.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Alexis Madrigal, Kara Oehler, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with CMS Nursing Home Data
item.description: Here’s what we know about the only federal dataset on COVID-19 outcomes in long-term care facilities.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Kara Oehler, Aarushi Sahejpal, & Dave Luo

item.title: Where to Find Simple COVID-19 Data for the US
item.description: As The COVID Tracking Project approaches its final day of data compilation on March 7, 2021, we are recommending a selection of federal data sources to people who want a quick and easy way to keep an eye on the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane

item.title: Good News Despite Data Wobbles: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 25
item.description: Cases, hospitalizations, and deaths are still declining, though holiday reporting and winter storms have probably caused fluctuations in several metrics. We reiterate that deaths reported each day don’t represent people who died that day—and they may even include deaths that occurred several months ago. And now is the time to switch over to federal data sources, because The COVID Tracking Project has only a little over a week of data compilation left.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Death Numbers
item.description: The CDC provides two different datasets regarding COVID-19 fatalities. Here’s a walkthrough of how they compare to each other and to The COVID Tracking Project’s data.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Bensimon & Quang P. Nguyen

item.title: Variants 101: FAQ
item.description: Coronavirus variants have emerged worldwide. What does this really mean?
item.dc:creator: Jacqueline Houtman, Lindsey Shultz, & Tong Wang

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Case Data
item.description: Here’s a walkthrough of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) daily case dataset and what you should know about it.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Clyde

item.title: How Day-of-Week Effects Impact COVID-19 Data
item.description: An understanding of state reporting schedules and day-of-week effects can help explain the reasons that numbers fluctuate from day to day, and what those changes mean.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Hoffman

item.title: More Good News: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 18
item.description: Case numbers are dropping rapidly, and deaths are down 20 percent from last week. Vaccines are finally showing up in the data with dramatic declines in deaths from long-term-care facilities. We urge caution about interpreting wobbles in the data in the next week or two, given storm disruptions affecting Texas and elsewhere.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Alexis Madrigal, Kara Oehler, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: Federal Testing Data’s Last Mile
item.description: Federal testing data is already more standardized and more detailed than the data we compile from states can ever be. But in some jurisdictions, state-provided data still provides a more comprehensive picture of testing volume. The federal government should address lingering quality problems so its data can become the national standard.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Federal COVID Data 101: Working with Hospitalization Numbers
item.description: Here’s a walkthrough of the Department of Health and Human Services’ dataset and what you should know about it.
item.dc:creator: Dave Luo & Catherine Pollack

item.title: Why Some States Won’t Share Race and Ethnicity Data on Vaccinations with the CDC—and Why That’s a Problem
item.description: We sent requests for data-use agreements to 56 states and territories to learn what vaccination data was being shared with the federal government. We found that several states—including California and Texas—aren’t sharing race and ethnicity data on vaccinations with the CDC, citing patient privacy laws. In better news, most states are.
item.dc:creator: Caitlin Antonios, Mohar Chatterjee, Georgia Gee, Derek Kravitz, & Kyra Senese

item.title: The Third Surge Continues to Ease: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 11
item.description: Another week of good news: Cases and hospitalizations continue to drop nationally, and deaths are down for the second week in a row. We’re concerned about ambiguous indicators in the Northeast, and about testing declines.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: A Better Approach to Comparing and Assessing State-Level COVID-19 Data Reporting
item.description: We’re replacing state letter grades with detailed and explanatory assessments of each state’s data.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb & Sara Simon

item.title: Learn More About Using Federal COVID-19 Data with The COVID Tracking Project
item.description: In February and March, we’ll hold a series of free trainings to help anyone who uses our data to understand existing federal numbers.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Glickhouse

item.title: Silent Data Mismatches Are Compromising Key COVID-19 Indicators
item.description: Although we’d prefer to have precise, real-time, comprehensive COVID-19 data for every US state and territory, the reality is that every metric that each jurisdiction publishes comes with quirks of timing and content that can make precise calculations impossible.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman & Sara Simon

item.title: The Numbers Are High but Improving: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Feb 4
item.description: Cases and hospitalizations continue to drop, and now COVID-19 deaths finally appear to be declining.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Catherine Pollack, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: It’s Time: The COVID Tracking Project Will Soon Come to an End
item.description: After a year of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting COVID-19 data for the United States, we’re ending our data compilation work in early March.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Alexis Madrigal

item.title: The State of COVID-19 Race and Ethnicity Data
item.description: We know COVID-19 is affecting Black, Indigenous, Latinx, and other people of color the most. But we need more and more standardized data to truly understand the impact to these communities—and to mitigate those disparities.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb

item.title: Outbreaks Ease Across the US, but Our Numbers Are Still Very High: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 28
item.description: COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations are dropping in almost every state—and dropping very quickly in some of our worst-hit areas. Hospitalizations are down another 10 percent but are still far above levels seen in previous surges. Deaths, which lag behind cases and hospitalizations, remain high.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Catherine Pollack, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: Encouraging Indicators Are Everywhere, But Deaths Remain High: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 21
item.description: With holiday reporting backlogs finally (mostly) behind us, we are seeing good signs in every region of the country.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Catherine Pollack, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: State-Level Vaccine Demographic Data is Messy and Incomplete—We Need Federal Data, Now
item.description: Only a third of states and territories with public vaccine data share information on the race and ethnicity of vaccine recipients, and those that do share it do so in highly unstandardized ways. But data from the federal government could answer the question of who’s getting vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb & Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Soaring Death Numbers and Highly Regional Outbreaks: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 14
item.description: Deaths are 25 percent higher than any other week since the pandemic began. Arizona has the worst per-capita new case numbers in the world. A month after the country’s first vaccinations for COVID-19, we still don’t have federal data showing who is receiving the vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Peter Walker, Kara Oehler, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Nicki Camberg, & Mandy Brown

item.title: Vaccine Distribution Data in Long-Term-Care Facilities Needs to Be Public
item.description: For the last month, the public has had minimal visibility into the roll out of COVID-19 vaccines to long-term-care facilities. Last week, South Carolina published the names of nursing homes and other long-term-care facilities where residents and staff have been vaccinated. States—and the CDC—should follow suit.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Aarushi Sahejpal, Erin Kissane, & Kara Oehler

item.title: The “Good” Metric Is Pretty Bad: Why It’s Hard to Count the People Who Have Recovered from COVID-19
item.description: We don’t know how many people in the US have really recovered from COVID-19.
item.dc:creator: Amanda French & Quang P. Nguyen

item.title: Visualizing COVID-19’s Impact on Hospitals Across the Country
item.description: The HHS released a facility-level data set on COVID-19 hospitalizations in December. We’ve taken that data and created an interactive map, allowing the public to see how their local hospitals are faring against this virus.
item.dc:creator: Dave Luo & Peter Walker

item.title: Record Hospitalizations Point to Trouble in California and the South: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Jan 6
item.description: The lingering effects of holiday data reporting are still making most COVID-19 metrics hard to contextualize this week. Hospitalization reporting remains relatively steady and suggests that outbreaks are lighting up across the US South. In Southern California and Arizona, the situation remains dire.
item.dc:creator: Mandy Brown, Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Kara Oehler, & Peter Walker

item.title: All Eyes on Hospitalizations: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 30
item.description: Holiday reporting has garbled most metrics. Going by current COVID-19 hospitalizations, outbreaks in the Midwest are still easing, but every other region is in trouble.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Peter Walker

item.title: In the Deadliest Month Yet, the Pandemic Is Regional Again: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 23
item.description: Three weeks in, we’ve seen more COVID-19 deaths in December than in any other month in the US pandemic. This milestone comes as the nationwide surge in cases has subsided back into regional variation: We see positive signs throughout the Midwest but worrying indicators in the South and West. California alone reported nearly 300,000 new cases this week.
item.dc:creator: Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Kara Oehler, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: How We Hope Vaccines Will Be Tracked
item.description: The federal government seems poised to provide high-quality data on vaccinations, but even a minimal dataset must answer key questions about who is getting vaccinated.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Madrigal & Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: How We Source Our Data and Why It Matters
item.description: States provide COVID-19 data in a variety of sources and formats. To ensure our data is as accurate and consistent as possible, we spend a lot of time looking at these sources to make sure that we’re capturing the most data possible for each state, while maintaining high standards of data quality and integrity. Today, we’re publicly releasing a detailed set of notes on the sources of all our data points.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Hoffman

item.title: Our New Homepage Is Designed to Get You to the Data, Fast
item.description: Our redesigned homepage puts information you can use right at the top of the page, gets you into the data more quickly, and surfaces analysis that can help you better understand COVID-19 in the US.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Miller & Hannah Birch

item.title: A Vaccine Arrives as Deaths Rise and Southern California Cases Soar: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 17
item.description: The news this week is extremely mixed: In the Midwest, cases and hospitalizations are falling. California reported a quarter of a million cases this week, and in Los Angeles County, one in 80 people has COVID-19. More than 50,000 Black Americans have died of COVID-19 as we near 300,000 total US COVID-19 deaths. The first doses of vaccine have arrived in hospitals and on their way to most US nursing homes, where cases continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Nicki Camberg, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Alexis Madrigal, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: Vaccines Begin to Arrive as Cases and Deaths Keep Rising: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 16
item.description: Cases are up and known deaths in long-term-care facilities are the highest they’ve been since late May.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Sarah McLaughlin, Kara Oehler, Aarushi Sahejpal, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: Test Types 101: The Pros and Cons of Different Approaches
item.description: Once limited to molecular tests, the United States now has other testing methods available. Their efficacy depends on multiple factors, including how far the person tested is in their infection and how high the test positivity is where they live.
item.dc:creator: Júlia Ledur & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: Current, New, and Cumulative Hospitalizations: What They Are and Why They Matter
item.description: COVID-19 hospitalizations continue to rise across the country, but the method in which they are reported can take several different forms. We dive into the meaning of some of the most common metrics and comment on why some may be more interpretable than others.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pollack & Dave Luo

item.title: New HHS dataset tells us precisely where COVID-19 is hitting hospitals
item.description: The Department of Health and Human Services released a new public dataset on December 7 that includes data down to the facility level on where COVID-19 patients are hospitalized and how healthcare systems are coping. We explored how to use this dataset and what patterns it can reveal.
item.dc:creator: Dave Luo, Rebecca Glassman, Betsy Ladyzhets, & Catherine Pollack

item.title: Our Worst Week Yet: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 10
item.description: Reported COVID-19 deaths hit all-time daily and weekly highs this week, and cases and hospitalizations continue to rise.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Charlotte Minsky, Joanna Pearlstein, & Peter Walker

item.title: Surge Continues as Northeast and West Coast Cases Spike: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 9
item.description: Long-term-care facilities continue to bear the brunt of this deadly virus. The latest surge continues in the Midwest and South, as COVID-19 cases in the Northeast and West begin to spike.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Sarah McLaughlin, Kara Oehler, Aarushi Sahejpal, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: What We've Learned About the HHS’s Hospitalization Data
item.description: Despite a rocky beginning, the current hospitalization and new admissions metrics from the HHS Protect public dataset have stabilized—and they’re now largely harmonious with state-reported hospitalization metrics if we account for differences in data definitions and reporting lag time.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Glassman, Erin Kissane, Dave Luo, Alexis Madrigal, & Peter Walker

item.title: Hospitalizations Break 100,000, Holiday Data Stalls Out: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Dec 3
item.description: Three of our four topline COVID-19 metrics are still recovering from data interruptions over the Thanksgiving holiday weekend. Meanwhile, hospitalizations are soaring.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Charlotte Minsky, Joanna Pearlstein, & Peter Walker

item.title: Long-Term Care Deaths Pass 100,000 as Outbreaks Surge: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Dec 2
item.description: Despite messy reporting due to the Thanksgiving holiday, this week saw continued high numbers of cases and deaths in long-term care communities. But relief may be on the way, as a CDC committee recommended that long-term care residents and staff be first in line to receive the coronavirus vaccine.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Sarah McLaughlin, Kara Oehler, Aarushi Sahejpal, Sara Simon, Peter Walker, & Nadia Zonis

item.title: As North Dakota’s Deaths Metrics Diverge, We’re Switching to a Less Backlogged Measure of Fatalities
item.description: North Dakota's growing backlog of death certificates means its count of individuals who died due to COVID is no longer an accurate measure of deaths in the state. As a result, we're switching our metric to deaths among cases, matching the state’s most prominent method of reporting.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman, Quang P. Nguyen, & Joseph Bensimon

item.title: Midwest Outbreaks Pause, Hospitalizations and Deaths Keep Rising: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 25
item.description: US states reported 1.2 million cases, and on three of the past seven days, the number of reported deaths exceeded 2,000. Nearly 90,000 people are hospitalized with COVID-19. After weeks of sharp rises, cases are declining in the Midwest.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Júlia Ledur, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Kara Oehler, Joanna Pearlstein, & Peter Walker

item.title: Nation Still Grappling with Long-Term Care Outbreaks as New Cases Double: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Nov 24
item.description: Nearly 40 percent of new COVID-19 cases in long-term care facilities came from the Midwest, and just three facilities in Wyoming were home to half of that state’s new resident and staff cases, a dire reminder of how easily COVID-19 spreads within close-contact environments.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Joanna Pearlstein, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Aarushi Sahejpal, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: Daily COVID-19 Data Is About to Get Weird
item.description: The upcoming holiday means that many COVID-19 metrics are going to drop—and then rise—in ways that may trip up unsuspecting observers. Here’s what to watch out for.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane

item.title: What We Know About Covid Testing Sensitivity
item.description: To successfully manage the pandemic, we need tools for both surveillance and diagnosis, in the form of antigen tests and PCR tests.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser

item.title: One Million Cases in Seven Days: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 19
item.description: Weekly cases grew 26 percent and nearly 80,000 people in the United States are hospitalized with COVID-19. That’s one-third higher than the nation’s previous record.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Alice Goldfarb, Erin Kissane, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Kara Oehler, Joanna Pearlstein, & Peter Walker

item.title: Cases Race Past Previous Highs: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, Nov 17
item.description: With COVID-19 cases surging across the country, long-term care facilities experienced their largest increase in six months. The LTC case surge is concentrated in the Midwest, mirroring the pattern of the US pandemic as a whole.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Aarushi Sahejpal, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Sara Simon, & Peter Walker

item.title: A Nationwide Case Surge Hits US Hospitals: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 12
item.description: One in 378 US residents tested positive for COVID-19 this week, and hospitalizations have nearly doubled in the past two weeks. The United States is posting new records for cases and hospitalizations nearly every day, and healthcare systems are reaching capacity in many areas where cases have spiked.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Ultralight Recommendations for a National Pandemic Dashboard
item.description: The announcement of a forthcoming national pandemic dashboard is heartening news for COVID-19 data folks all over the country. We have a few modest suggestions for the team that will undertake this work.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: The Third Wave of COVID-19 Deaths in Long-Term Care Facilities is Here: This Week in Long-Term Care COVID-19 Data, November 11
item.description: In October, eight percent of long-term care facility residents diagnosed with COVID-19 died. The rising cases of the past few weeks are resulting in the highest number of deaths in months as states and facilities fail to protect these most vulnerable Americans.
item.dc:creator: Artis Curiskis, Erin Kissane, Kara Oehler, Jessica Malaty Rivera, Aarushi Sahejpal, Sara Simon, Peter Walker, & Nadia Zonis

item.title: COVID-19 Hospitalizations Have Hit an All-Time High
item.description: More people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than ever before, and the per-capita hospitalization rates in the Midwest have now surpassed those of the South in the summer’s Sunbelt surge. Hospitals across the country are warning of staff and PPE shortages, and case rates continue to spike in every US region.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Madrigal & Erin Kissane

item.title: Introducing the COVID Tracking Project City Dataset
item.description: Our new data collection tracks the spread of COVID-19 in 65 cities and counties across the United States, and it lets us see how fatality rates vary widely across geographies.
item.dc:creator: Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Kara Oehler, Judith Oppenheim, Catherine Pollack, Aarushi Sahejpal, & Sharon Wang

item.title: Cases Still Rising, Hospitalizations Spiking, Nursing Homes in Trouble: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Nov 5
item.description: COVID-19 is surging in large midwestern states while continuing to burn through heavily rural states in the Mountain West. Testing growth has slowed, and new outbreaks are rising in long-term care facilities. Nationally, deaths are up 8 percent, and on Wednesday the United States broke 100,000 new cases a day.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Third Surge Brings Record-Breaking Case Rates Across the Nation, This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 29
item.description: Unlike the spring and summer outbreaks, the third surge is geographically dispersed, and counts are up in every region of the country. An increase in testing is not sufficient to explain the numbers.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: COVID-19 Deaths Are Rising, But Fatality Rates Have Improved
item.description: As COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations once again rise across the United States so, inevitably, will deaths. But there is reason to hope that we will not see the devastating fatality rates of the initial spring surge.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Good News about Florida’s Testing Data
item.description: Florida is now publishing a full time series of test encounters, so we are picking up this metric in our API and on our website.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman & Michal Mart

item.title: Cases Matter
item.description: As COVID-19 cases rise across the United States, claims are circulating that case increases are (mostly or entirely) due to expanded testing, and do not indicate a spike in infections. The data does not support this conclusion.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: The Third Surge Worsens as Hospitalizations and Deaths Rise Nationwide. Plus a New Tool for Understanding Racial Data: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 22
item.description: The surge in COVID-19 cases spread across the Midwest as Illinois and Indiana saw case growth alongside neighbors Wisconsin and the Dakotas. Hospitalizations rose in 39 US states, and nationally, deaths began to climb once again.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: The State of State Antigen Test Reporting
item.description: Antigen tests are becoming a major tool for rapid COVID-19 testing. But if states don’t report results clearly, we won’t know the true impact of these tests.
item.dc:creator: Betsy Ladyzhets & Quang P. Nguyen

item.title: The Third Surge Has Arrived. Plus, Updates on Data from Long-Term Care Facilities: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 15
item.description: Fall has brought a third surge of COVID-19. The data across US regions moved in tandem this week as case and hospitalization numbers rose almost everywhere.
item.dc:creator: The COVID Tracking Project

item.title: Worrisome Data as the Weather Turns: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 8
item.description: An outbreak in the White House has turned attention away from the broader outlines of the pandemic. However, cases nationally rose for the fourth consecutive week and hospitalizations have followed, causing serious strain on some states’ health care systems.
item.dc:creator: Nadia Zonis & Peter Walker

item.title: Test Positivity in the US Is a Mess
item.description: Interpreted correctly, test positivity can tell us so much that we need to know about COVID-19 outbreaks and testing in the United States. But we don’t publish test positivity calculations for US states and territories. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: Good News in the Big Picture, but Regional and Weekly Views More Troubling: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Oct 1
item.description:
Cases in the Dakotas and Wisconsin continue their troubling rise, but in September the average daily number of cases, hospitalizations, and deaths fell nationwide.
After a difficult summer, averaged metrics for August and September showed drops in COVID-19 cases, hospitalizations, and deaths at the national level. At the same time, indicators in a few states are ringing alarm bells, and this week’s data continues a three-week rise in cases, with hospitalizations starting to increase as well.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Joanna Pearlstein

item.title: Trends Improve Except in the Midwest: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 24
item.description: The Midwest and certain Western states showed a rise in case numbers and an uptick in hospitalizations, even as other regions continued to decline. The US reported over 6 million weekly tests for the first time this year, though some states are now lumping antigen tests results into standard PCR test data.
item.dc:creator: Peter Walker & Joanna Pearlstein

item.title: Test Positivity: So Valuable, So Easy to Misinterpret
item.description: Test positivity is extremely useful, but it has also become one of the most commonly misunderstood metrics for monitoring the COVID-19 pandemic. Here, we take a step back and look at what it really means.
item.dc:creator: Júlia Ledur, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Tong Wang

item.title: Why The COVID Tracking Project’s Death Count Hasn’t Hit 200,000
item.description: Several sites tracking the progression of the virus hit a grim milestone today: more than 200,000 deaths since the pandemic began. Our figures haven’t yet reached that level. Here’s why.
item.dc:creator: Sara Simon

item.title: Holiday Reporting Lags Interrupt Positive Trends: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 17
item.description: Though cases are rising in parts of the Midwest, hospitalizations in the West and South continued trending downward. The Labor Day holiday impacted data reporting lag times both this week and last, obscuring what had been positive trends in September.
item.dc:creator: Joanna Pearlstein & Peter Walker

item.title: State-level data obscures important variations in how cities and counties experience COVID-19
item.description: We track and analyze data from cities and counties, including breakdowns by race, ethnicity, and ZIP code when possible. The differences we find between cities, counties, and states give useful insights into response efforts.
item.dc:creator: Nicki Camberg, Artis Curiskis, Kara Oehler, Catherine Pollack, & Aarushi Sahejpal

item.title: The Tech Partners Who Make This Work Possible
item.description: Our volunteer-powered work depends on the contributions of hundreds of individuals, but it also wouldn’t be possible without the support of the tech companies that have donated their services to help us connect with each other, run a fast and stable website and API, and tell the stories emerging from the data we compile.
item.dc:creator: Asia Lindsay

item.title: Testing In Limbo, Hospitalizations and Deaths Still Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 10
item.description: A long holiday weekend makes ambiguous testing data even harder to understand, but hospitalizations are dropping, which is good.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Peter Walker

item.title: Cases Stop Dropping and the Midwest Heats Up: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Sep 3
item.description: After five straight weeks of sharp declines in new cases of COVID-19 in the United States, we’ve leveled off again. Reported tests are up about 5 percent, but are actually dropping in the Midwest, where three states—Iowa, North Dakota, and South Dakota—are driving an uptick in new cases. This week we also launched a new dataset that looks closely at the toll of COVID-19 in nursing homes and other long-term care facilities.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane, Peter Walker, & Rebecca Glassman

item.title: Introducing the Long-Term Care COVID Tracker: Tracing COVID-19’s Dramatic Toll on a Uniquely Vulnerable Population
item.description: Our new dataset shows how COVID-19 has travelled through the nation’s long-term care facilities. The virus has killed one out of every 28 long-term care residents in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser & Conor Kelly

item.title: Testing Looks Shaky But National Progress Continues: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 27
item.description: New COVID-19 cases continued their steady decline this week, a positive signal supported by a similar decline in hospitalized patients. Reported deaths also fell for the second straight week. Though testing across the US can’t seem to regain the peak of late July, we believe conditions on the ground are improving across the country—and that the data states report is, by and large, trustworthy. Read on to find out why.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane

item.title: We've Redesigned The COVID Tracking Project Site—Again—To Bring You More and Richer Data
item.description: In our fifth month of compiling COVID-19 data from 56 US states and territories, we have redesigned the data displays and annotations on our website to reveal more of the data each state and territory publishes and sharpen the contextual information that runs alongside it.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Miller

item.title: COVID-19 Race and Ethnicity Data: What’s Changed, and What Still Needs Improvement
item.description: Even with significant data unreported, the disproportionate impact of COVID-19 on communities of color is clear.
item.dc:creator: Alice Goldfarb & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: Finally, Some Good News. This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 20
item.description: Key data points in our COVID-19 tracking are finally beginning to trend positively. In the South, tests rose while cases fell, a pattern not seen there since early spring. Hospitalizations fell for the third week straight, but deaths remained above 1,000 a day on average.
item.dc:creator: Peter Walker & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: Something Is Wrong with Testing Data in the Great State of Texas
item.description: According to the official state numbers, COVID-19 testing has dropped dramatically in August. However, county-level statistics show the opposite story. What’s going on?
item.dc:creator: Conor Kelly, Judith Oppenheim, & Pat Kelly

item.title: Counting COVID-19 Tests: How States Do It, How We Do It, and What’s Changing
item.description: Many states have moved toward greater transparency about their test data reporting methods, and we’re making changes to better represent what they publish. We’re also introducing a “new” way some states are counting tests—one we think all states and territories would be wise to embrace.
item.dc:creator: Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Tests, Cases, and Hospitalizations Keep Dropping: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 13
item.description: Testing continues to fall, especially in the South, one of the areas where the country needs it the most. Cases, too, are falling, which remains hard to interpret, given the testing decline—but fewer people are now in the hospital with COVID-19 than last week. This is the second week in a row that hospitalizations seem to have dropped, which suggests that infections may be declining independently of testing reductions.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Madrigal & Peter Walker

item.title: Hospitalization Data Reported by the HHS vs. the States: Jumps, Drops, and Other Unexplained Phenomena
item.description: In mid-July the federal government began requiring hospitals to report COVID-19 data to the HHS rather than to the CDC. We compared current hospitalization data reported by the federal government and state health departments since the switch, and found contradictions that suggest the federal data continue to be unreliable, while the state datasets face their own challenges.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Glassman & Betsy Ladyzhets

item.title: The Last Thing We Need Is Fewer Tests: This Week in COVID-19 Data, Aug 6
item.description: This week’s data marks a return to ambiguities we last saw in April and May. For the first time, we saw week-over-week testing numbers fall—and this decline makes drops in new COVID-19 case numbers difficult to interpret. Deaths continued their steady rise. And new complications like technical glitches and school reopenings threaten to cloud the picture even further.
item.dc:creator: Peter Walker & Erin Kissane

item.title: Is There a Right Way to Chart COVID-19 Deaths Over Time?
item.description: States across the US use two primary methods for announcing COVID-19 deaths: date of death (reported) and date of death (actual). To analyze how the pandemic is trending across the country, understanding the relationship between these two data points is crucial. Here's what we've learned from investigating both methods in three of our largest hotspots: Arizona, Florida, and Texas.
item.dc:creator: Peter Walker

item.title: Florida’s Per-Capita COVID-19 Cases Just Surpassed New York’s, but Are the Two Outbreaks Comparable? Yes and No.
item.description: Florida has reported over 461,000 total COVID-19 cases, surpassing New York for the highest per-capita caseload in the United States—but a simple comparison doesn’t represent the critical differences in the data we have for the two outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Júlia Ledur & Emma Rubin

item.title: Cases Declining, Deaths Rising, Hospital Data Remains a Question Mark: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 30
item.description: This week’s data brings the first good news in several weeks: new cases of COVID-19 are declining nationally, thanks to substantial declines in reported cases by states with major outbreaks. Deaths, which lag cases, continue to rise. And hospital data is still unreliable for the second week in a row.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: What’s Going on with COVID-19 Hospitalization Data?
item.description: Data for current COVID-19 hospitalizations in the United States—one of our most valuable metrics for understanding the pandemic and its effects—has become highly erratic in recent weeks. Here's what we've learned from watching the data closely, and from our initial analysis of the hospitalization data being published by the federal government.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane, Robinson Meyer, & Peter Walker

item.title: Erratic Hospital Numbers, Deaths Still Rising: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 23
item.description: The rise in new cases is slowing, but so is testing growth. Hospitalization data was highly erratic this week, but what we did see is alarming. Deaths are rising three weeks behind cases, which suggests a very difficult few weeks ahead for the United States.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Madrigal, Peter Walker, & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: The Unchecked Rise in Cases Turns Deadly: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 16
item.description: The US is approaching half a million new cases of COVID-19 each week. States with major outbreaks including Arizona, California, Florida, and Texas all saw record high weekly hospitalizations and deaths. Meanwhile, worsening outbreaks in many other states threaten to increase the pandemic's death toll in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Peter Walker

item.title: The State of the States’ Data
item.description: Since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, US states and territories have released more and more data. While there are still notable gaps in the data, the quality of the data offered by the states has improved dramatically.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Scholl

item.title: Record New Cases, Surging Hospitalizations, Rising Deaths: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 9
item.description: The South continues to be the epicenter of surges in both cases and hospitalizations. In Arizona, Florida, South Carolina, and Texas, COVID-19 deaths have begun to climb following jumps in new cases. And for the first time since April, deaths are rising nationally.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Malaty Rivera & Alice Goldfarb

item.title: Confirmed and Probable COVID-19 Deaths, Counted Two Ways
item.description: We're up to 24 states publishing both confirmed and probable COVID-19 deaths, and we're adding those data points into our API. But states are also using two different ways of deciding which deaths to count as COVID-19 deaths.
item.dc:creator: Quang P. Nguyen & Kara W. Schechtman

item.title: Florida’s COVID-19 Data: What We Know, What’s Wrong, and What’s Missing
item.description: Before it made headlines with a sudden resurgence of its outbreak—and despite receiving early praise for its transparency—Florida’s COVID-19 data has been mired in trouble. Under public pressure and threat of lawsuits, the Florida Department of Health has gradually released more data, but some very important pieces remain missing.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca Glassman & Olivier Lacan

item.title: To Understand the US Pandemic, We Need Hospitalization Data—and We Almost Have It
item.description: Hospitalization data can help us understand the severity of COVID-19 outbreaks in the United States, and even see a little bit of what's to come. Until very recently, we didn't have a national summary figure—now we can finally piece together a national statistic from states that provide it, and estimate the rest.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser & Conor Kelly

item.title: This Week in COVID-19 Data, July 2: Across the US, Outbreaks Are Catching Fire
item.description: The US has broken its record for new COVID-19 cases three times in the last week. Thirteen states broke their new-case records since Sunday. In the states with the worst outbreaks, hospitalizations and deaths are rising.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Alexis Madrigal

item.title: Better COVID-19 Data Is Coming By August 1—But Will the Public See It?
item.description: Starting in August, new federal rules will require testing labs to report better data on the spread of COVID-19 in the United States. What happens to this new information is up to state and local officials. Journalists, open-data advocates, and members of the public can help us hold governments accountable for collecting and publishing this urgently needed data.
item.dc:creator: Michael Parks & Nicole Rivera

item.title: The Other COVID-19 Metric We Should Be Using
item.description: As exposure risk increases, so does the need for more testing. The more we test, the more cases we can identify—which is a good thing. But are we looking at the right metrics to know if we are performing enough tests?
item.dc:creator: Tong Wang, Jessica Malaty Rivera, & Júlia Ledur

item.title: Why Changing COVID-19 Demographics in the US Make Death Trends Harder to Understand
item.description: COVID-19 death data lags behind testing data in ways we mostly understand. What we only partly understand is how an infection rate that seems to be skewing younger will affect the death toll in surging regional outbreaks.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser

item.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 25: The US Pandemic Is Surging in the South and West
item.description: The United States hit a record high for new COVID-19 cases this week. In many areas with rising case counts, testing isn’t keeping up. Meanwhile, hospitalizations in regions with big outbreaks are increasing.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Peter Walker

item.title: It's Not Just Testing
item.description: As case counts surge, we look at regional and state-level numbers to find out which recent jumps in COVID-19 case counts are likely to be explained by increased testing, and which are not. For the states with the worst recent numbers, the news is not good.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Jessica Malaty Rivera

item.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 18: The Regional Gap Widens
item.description: As cases and hospitalizations continue to drop in the early Northeast epicenters, they are rising—in some areas quite sharply—in the South and West. We look at the numbers and at the relationship between an increase in tests and a rise in case counts.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Malaty Rivera & Peter Walker

item.title: What Is a Probable Case of COVID-19?
item.description: Probable cases of COVID-19 make up only a small fraction of currently reported cases, but the CDC wants states to do a better job reporting them. So what are they and why do they matter? We took a closer look to help reporters and members of the public better understand this complex COVID-19 metric.
item.dc:creator: Erin Kissane & Quang P. Nguyen

item.title: Weekly COVID-19 Data Update, June 11: Early Data from May Transmission
item.description: The news this week is mixed and highly regional. In the early US epicenter of the outbreak, cases continue to drop. In the southern and western United States, cases are on the rise, as are COVID-19 hospitalizations. And as always, the lag makes the data difficult to put into context.
item.dc:creator: Peter Walker & Erin Kissane

item.title: Early COVID-19 Race Data Shows Disproportionate Loss of Black Lives—It's Time for States to Release the Rest of the Data
item.description: We're still missing vital race and ethnicity data, but where the data is strongest—official COVID-19 death rates—the toll of longstanding public health inequities within Black communities is painfully clear. Five months into the US outbreak, several states are still not collecting or releasing complete demographic data required to address these disparities and safely re-open state economies. It's time for this to change.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Malaty Rivera & Alice Goldfarb

item.title: Tracking the States and the CDC
item.description: For months, we've worked to patch together inconsistent state-reported data into a national set of numbers for COVID-19 case, death, and testing in the US. The CDC has now published a COVID Data Tracker, but their data only partially matches the numbers we get from the state public health authorities. So we took a closer look.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Malaty Rivera & Amber Wojcek

item.title: Position Statement on Antibody Data Reporting
item.description: As antibody tests become more widely available across the United States, we call on all states and territories to preserve the integrity and usefulness of their COVID-19 testing data by maintaining separate viral testing and antibody testing counts.
item.dc:creator: Quang P. Nguyen & Erin Kissane

item.title: We’re Launching a New State Grading System
item.description: We're rolling out a new, more rigorous system for grading the public health data each state reports. This new scoring system sets a more comprehensive and exact standard for evaluating how complete and meaningful each state’s data is.
item.dc:creator: Prajakta Ranade & Harrison Frank

item.title: Tracking Race and Ethnicity in the COVID-19 Pandemic
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic isn't affecting all communities the same way. That's why we're partnering with American University’s Antiracist Research & Policy Center to launch a new project: the COVID Racial Data Tracker.
item.dc:creator: Alexis Madrigal
